dict.string: v. deprive through death
Stay in touch through phone calls, visits and cards, and remind the bereaved that you're thinking about them and their loved one who died.
What do you say to the bereaved family at a funeral, for instance?
if sb is bereaved, a relative or close friend has died
adj. easy to shape or bend
adj. in good taste, orderly
He is an incisive writer and a disciplined and decorous filmmaker, framing and cutting his scenes with clean, almost classical economy.
He adds: "I'm now married a wonderful, decorous veiled woman and have lovely children, may God save them and her."
Something that is decorous is dignified, proper, and in good taste, like your decorous great-aunt who always wears a dress - even when she's only headed to the grocery store.
adj. unimaginative; unfruitful; infertile
v. to clear all blame or suspicion
v. show to be right by providing justification or proof
adly, not everyone is able to vindicate their company, nor are individuals, as the case may be.
"We will use all of our resources to vindicate my client's rights and hold those responsible for their actions," Mr. Wigdor said.

Vindicate means to justify, prove, or reinforce an idea - or to absolve from guilt. If your family thinks you hogged the last piece of pie on Thanksgiving, you'll be vindicated when your younger brother fesses up.
adj. rebirth or revival
Hopper was also a Renaissance man who never lost his wild, rebellious nature.
Artworks, and marvelous architecture, are everywhere in Florence, the enduring heritage of its Renaissance glory.
the period of European history at the close of the Middle Ages and the rise of the modern world; a cultural rebirth from the 14th through the middle of the 17th centuries
n. someone chosen to judge and decide a disputed issue
n. someone with the power to settle matters at will
The Better Business Bureau, which was established in 1912, is a non-profit organization that serves as an arbiter between consumers and businesses.
They buy patents from inventors and each other, creating a marketplace that checks big tech companies' sway, and rely ultimately on a fair arbiter: courts.
The law is the final arbiter of what is considered obscene.
An arbiter is someone selected to judge and settle a dispute. When Doc and Grumpy disagreed over whose turn it was to stay late at the mine, they chose Snow White as an arbiter
adj. fertile; productive
a. including all, or almost all, the items, details, facts, information, etc
This list is far from comprehensive - it's just a sampling of the types of pot-related businesses that are interesting investors at this point.
The insurance system should be designed to financially protect people from low-probability events, rather than provide comprehensive coverage for all health events, as Obamacare envisions.
The city lacks a comprehensive mental-health-care system, and cops are often called to assist people in the midst of psychotic episodes.

When you want to describe something that includes all or most details, you can use the adjective comprehensive. If you get the comprehensive treatment at a spa, it might include massage, manicure and a facial.
adj. avoiding waste, economical
Frugal shopping is often associated with coupons, deals and everyday purchases.
China's consumers are notoriously frugal, with a household savings rate among the highest in the world for a large economy.
A person who lives simply and economically can be called frugal. Buying clothes at a consignment shop would be considered frugal.
n. the combination of ideas into a complex whole
Two earlier Rodgers and Hammerstein musicals, "Oklahoma!" and "Carousel," had been smashes, bringing a new synthesis of drama, music and dancing to Broadway.
It is the synthesis of these two opposite worlds into a functioning whole that is the key to meaningful, purposeful and productive organizations.
Synthesis is the act of combining elements to form something new. If you describe your bedroom decor as a synthesis of Andy Warhol and Punk Rock, we'll know you mean a mixture of these two styles.
adj. likely to cause disagreement between people
adj. liking to argue, involving a lot of arguing
The refusal sets up another confrontation between the automaker and federal regulators in what has already been a contentious issue.
The meeting also heard a presentation that touched on the contentious issue of whether to allow emergency deer feeding during harsh winters.
Perhaps the most contentious aspect of the plan is its price tag
A contentious issue is one that people are likely to argue about, and a contentious person is someone who likes to argue or fight.
adj. able to be done
Most experts agree that remission is feasible, and that, to some degree, we will be able to wean patients off lifelong therapies.
Which could mean that at least for some, Uber is not economically feasible as a full-time job.
If something is feasible, then you can do it without too much difficulty. When someone asks "Is it feasible?" the person is asking if you'll be able to get something done.
adj. inactive; sluggish; not reacting chemically
Even then I kept seeing the soldier's body tumbling toward the water, splashing down hard, how inert and heavy it was, how completely dead.
To Mr. Rose, it's provocative because it maps a sophisticated human emotion, anxiety, onto an inert, or dumb, object
The chubby, inert pet dog has become a familiar household sight in richer countries
Something that's unable to move or moving without much energy can be described as inert. Or when something or someone appears lifeless, the adjective to use is inert.
v. to hide the seriousness of sth with excuses or apologies
v. lessen or to try to lessen the seriousness or extent of
During the interval of these few hours of abandonment nothing can palliate or excuse, George Borrow died as he had lived-alone!
"The word palliate means 'to remove suffering,'" Anderson says, in whatever form it takes

When you palliate something, you try to make something less bad: Your dentist might give you pain-killing drugs to palliate the discomfort caused by an impacted molar, but that molar is still there, waiting to cause more trouble.
n. a statement that contradicts itself
n. a statement containing 2 opposite ideas features that make it seems impossible or unlikely
Managers intent on achieving such self-organization, however, face a paradox: self-organization suggests the absence of management, so what's a manager to do?
It is a paradox that every dictator has climbed to power on the ladder of free speech.
When Oscar Wilde said, "I can resist anything except temptation," he used a paradox to point to our fundamental weakness to give in to tempting things (like chocolate or a pretty smile).

A paradox is a logical puzzler that contradicts itself in a baffling way. Example: "This statement is false." If you think it's true, then it must be false, but if you think it's false, it must be true. Now, that's a paradox!
adj. lenient; yielding to desire
adj. being favorably inclined
Being indulgent towards radical Islamism is the same as being indulgent towards Nazism, he told reporters.
The coming weeks will be packed with parties, treats and indulgent annual traditions.
Tip #3: Stop Being an Over Indulgent Grandparent. I know how tempting it is to shower your grandkids with toys and stuff.
Someone who is self-indulgent gives themselves a lot of treats. Parents who are indulgent cave to ever desire their child expresses. Indulgent means lenient, or overly generous
n. a feeling of intense dislike, hatred;
n. the object of a feeling of intense aversion; something to be avoided
But the G20 summit is an international gathering, convened by members who do not all share the West's antipathy for Russia's president.
And despite Europeans' perceived antipathy toward American tech companies like Amazon and Facebook, the companies continue to have strong followings across the 28-country bloc.
An antipathy is a deep-seated dislike of something or someone. Usually it's a condition that is long-term, innate, and pretty unlikely to change - like your antipathy for the Red Sox.
v. to urge forcefully; to taunt someone into doing something
adj. easily managed or controlled; obedient
I am persuaded that you will find in him an obedient and tractable son.
It's huge to show it's a tractable, manageable problem.

If your little brother quietly obeys your instructions and waits for you at the food court while you and your friends wander around the mall, he's probably a tractable child, meaning he's obedient, flexible, and responds well to directions.
adj. marked by the exercise of good judgment or common sense in practical matters
He is judicious and does not choose controversy until left without option.
His carefully cultivated persona was of a uniquely thoughtful, judicious, deliberative, evidence-driven man comfortable with complexity.
If you're judicious, you've got a good head on your shoulders and make good decisions. Humpty Dumpty's decision to sit on a wall? NOT judicious.
adj. suing sarcasm or irony
Even in his creative work he had a satiric bent; his early training and associations, too, had been in journalistic satire.
The Onion stopped publishing its print edition in 2013, in spite of its satiric boast that print revenues were up "5,000 percent."
exposing human folly to ridicule
adj. frantic, frenzied
But he is still trying to figure out an American culture that is more frenetic and obstreperous than in his homeland.
But according to a survey from Thomson Reuters Thomson Reuters, this calm performance was hiding some frenetic, behind the scenes activity.
The adj frenetic is another way to say frenzied, frantic, or totally worked up. Kind of how you'd run around the kitchen madly trying to cook a last-minute dinner for 30 of your closest friends.
adj. full of energy, excitement and happiness
adj. strong and healthy, growing quickly and well
This show, he says, "includes quiet moments and meditation as well as exuberant playfulness."
"He painted and sculpted with it. In a Caribbean context, with a tropical exuberant landscape, his architecture remains revolutionary.
As night fell across Paris, the quiet and reflective mood of the day turned exuberant and joyful.
Are you feeling really happy and enthusiastic about something? Describe yourself with the adjective, exuberant!
v. to annoy; to pester; to worry
The Jets' troubles vex Ryan, his coaching staff and the players.
If something vexes you, it brings you trouble or difficulty. In other words, it annoys, worries, distresses, irritates, bothers, or puzzles you.
v. spread or diffuse through
v. pass through
v. penetrate mutually or be interlocked
"Let's spread that out and really have it permeate the whole team to where that's who we are."
As mobile devices continue to permeate our personal lives, the demand for corporate mobile apps continues to rise.
Many organizations would like to create more innovative teams or to have a more innovative culture permeate the organization.
The verb permeate literally means to "pass through." It's often used to describe smells or liquids that not only pass through, but also spread to fill an entire area.
v. to show sth clearly, esp a feeling, an attitude or a quality
adj. easy to see or understand
n. a list of goods or passengers on a ship or plane
The anger he felt is manifest in his paintings.
The buildings in Rome manifest a high level of architectural sophistication.
Choose the v. manifest when someone shows sth for everyone to notice. As an adj, manifest is a formal way to say that sth is apparent to the senses and is synonymous with evident, apparent, or clear
v. spread or diffuse through
Similar sentiments of loneliness, doubt and fear pervade most of Broken Bells' songs.
Having wired up the world, Silicon Valley assured us that the magic of technology would naturally pervade every corner of our lives.
Myths and stereotypes still pervade throughout society and have the potential to influence jurors too.
To pervade means to be present throughout, to exist in every part of. If you have too many cats, the horrible smell of cat pee will pervade your house.
adj. (of a body of water) free from disturbance by heavy waves
adj. not easily irritated
He seemed placid to me on the platform, but something about that stillness makes me wary now.
This is the Loch Ness-monster side of the Web-the unknown something lurking beneath the placid surface.
Call a body of water placid if it has a smooth surface and no waves. Call a person placid if they don't tend to make waves by causing a fuss
a. acutely insightful and wise
Of course, some pigeons are more sagacious, cleverer than others; but the fact remains, and everything tends to prove it.
Mr. Jones was a man of the world, and, moreover, was a wise and sagacious man of business.
Use the formal adjective, sagacious, to describe someone who is wise and insightful like an advisor to the president or a Supreme Court justice.
adj. unbiased
adj. ambiguous; intentially confusing; capable of being interpreted in more than 1 way
As such, Middleberg said the results are "equivocal" -- meaning they neither prove nor disprove that Klein was poisoned.
Cable news channels carrying the equivocal and morally ambivalent remarks used a split screen to show rioters in Ferguson lighting fires and looting store.
Try to remember that uncertain means equivocal and certain means unequivocal. That's a tricky movement the un- is making, and a lot of people get stumped.
v. to converse, to formally discuss about a subject
n. an extended communication (often interactive) dealing with some particular topic
With one young woman's life story in the public discourse, the national conversation about Death with Dignity has changed permanently.
The political discourse around immigration, he added, "becomes very heated and very angry and sometimes the rhetoric is not healthy".
If you use the word discourse, you are describing a formal and intense discussion or debate
adj. softly bright or radiant
The fish is known for it's luminous fishing hook, which attracts smaller fish.
Her face lit up; she was so pale, so luminous under the streetlight, that wasn't just an expression
Luminous means full of or giving off light. During the winter holidays, with all their emphasis on light, you can see luminous displays of candles everywhere.
adj. unwarily simple;; candid; naïve
adj. showing too much support for one person or group, esp without considering it carefully
n. a member of an armed group that is fighting secretly against enemy soldiers who have taken control of its country
Given how sluggish things happen in Congress - made worse by partisan politics - I don't hold out much hope that the policy will come to pass.
It was a very partisan speech, even though the president said he was going to offer policies that were "practical, not partisan".
Supporters told the committee the current system minimizes partisan politics in selecting justices and shouldn't be changed.

If something is prejudicial towards a particular point of view, you can call it partisan. You'll often hear of the partisan politics in the US - since politicians seem to be so devoted to either the Republican or Democratic parties
n. an embankment designed to prevent the flood of a river
n. a formal reception of visitors or guests (as at a royal court)
When the river is high, specially designed gates would be opened in the river levee, allowing freshwater and sediment to wash over nearby areas.
She opposes his tsunami-protection levee plan and enjoys Korean culture while he battles with Seoul.
A levee is an embankment, like a dam, constructed to prevent the overflow of a body of water. It can also mean a formal reception
v. to delay or stop the progress of sth
v. block passage through
That type of barrier to travel would impede business and tourism – and cost jobs.
To impede something is to delay or block its progress or movement. Carrying six heavy bags will impede your progress if you're trying to walk across town.
adj. sneaky; secret; marked by quiet and caution and secrecy; taking pains to avoid being observed
adj. conducted with or marked by hidden aims or methods
His video implication after capturing a multitude of Chinese buyers making surreptitious handoffs for cash?
Google Glass garnered plenty of attention, but as a consumer item, it's fallen flat as worries about privacy and surreptitious surveillance prevailed.
When someone behaves in a surreptitious way, they're being secretive. They're doing something that they don't want to be seen doing.
v. to promote the growth or development of
adj. excessively conspicuous; showing off
adj. (of a display) tawdry or vulgar
They drove the biggest cars, wore the most flamboyant clothing, and built the most ostentatious houses.
And while Matthews may add a touch of the ostentatious, Wagner will do things far more quietly, yet just as fiercely.

No one wants to be described as ostentatious, a word whose cousins include pretentious, flamboyant, and gaudy. Someone wailing especially loudly at a funeral of a distant acquaintance might be making an ostentatious show of sorrow.
adj. harmful
n. an aberration; an irregularity; a deviation
n. a person who is unusual
Lightning Rods is therefore that true anomaly in fiction: a novel that works beautifully despite having no real characters, no real conflict, no real story.
I do most of my work in Google Docs, Sheets, and Gmail, but I'm an anomaly; most professionals use Word, Excel, and Outlook.
An anomaly is an abnormality, a blip on the screen of life that doesn't fit with the rest of the pattern.
v. to subdue and dominate; to enslave
v. put down by force or intimidation
White South Africans were living in a dream world, he thought, if they believed they could continue to subjugate the majority of the country's population.
White people created the social construct of race to subjugate people of color, so you are the only ones who can change it.
They subjugate women, free speech, freedom of religion - pretty much all of the rights modern, intelligent societies hold dear.
If you say you won't be kept down by the man, you are saying that you won't let the man subjugate you. To subjugate is to repress someone, or to make them subservient to you.
adj. promoting health
v. to measure the depth of sth
Two years later, after Nick Hornby had adapted Strayed's story for the big screen, it was Witherspoon's turn to plumb the author's depths.
But it doesn't deeply plumb the complexities of the text.
To plumb a body of water, you measure its depth. To plumb a house, you connect all of its pipes. To make carpentry plumb, you get it exactly vertical.
n. a powerful argument made in refutation of something
adj. of or involving dispute or controversy
They also declared it would be a place free of "all party-cant-words, polemics and controversy, religious, national and political."
For a long time, I admired his insightful science writing, his fierce polemics, his uncompromising passion for the truth.
A polemic is something that stirs up controversy by having a negative opinion, usually aimed at a particular group. A piece of writing can be a polemic, as long as it gets someone's goat.
adj. pungent; attracting or delighting; engagingly stimulating or provocative
Crisps need to deliver simple, powerful flavours: saltiness, something sharp and piquant, something incredibly umami and savoury, or preferably a combination of all three.
It's a little like white wine, and it has delicious, piquant qualities which I think would go well with fish.

Someone who's piquant engages you with charm and wit. A story that's filled with piquant details has plenty of juicy, provocative points. And grandma's homemade gravy? It's certainly zesty and piquant, even with all the lumps.
n. an artistic class or category
This attitude has allowed the festival to organically expand to include different genres of music, film, and technology.
The two genres each have their strengths, and each does things better than the other.
A genre is a specific type of music, film, or writing. Your favorite literary genre might be science fiction, and your favorite film genre might be horror flicks about cheerleaders. Go figure.
n. a harsh-sounding mixture of words, voices, or sounds
v. to conclude by reasoning, to deduce
Although we cannot yet infer any causal relationships, rising student debt levels have, to an extent, coincided with falling entrepreneurship rates among young people.
The participants were then asked to infer people's emotional states based on facial expressions and non-verbal cues.

When you infer, you listen closely to someone and guess at things they mean but haven't actually said. It's like guessing, but not making wild guesses but a well informed guess - if you see your mom's bag on the table, you might infer that she's home.
adj. implied rather than expressly stated
adj. complete without doubt or reserve
We have an implicit assumption that intelligence and rationality go together-or else why would we be so surprised when smart people do foolish things?
Liberals show a greater gap between explicit attitudes and implicit attitudes and behavior than do conservatives.
So what is "implicit bias," and how is it different from the more overt bias we typically focus on when discussing racism in this country?
Use the adjective implicit when you mean that something is understood but not clearly stated.
v. prove capable or fit; meet requirements
v. to modify or restrict
This serious situation requires those who qualify to prove that their condition is either terminal or that it has or will continue for five years.
"Leviathan" was shown quietly in just one St. Petersburg theater last year to qualify for the Oscars.
In one sense, it means to be right for, to measure up. In another sense, though, qualify means to change something slightly, to limit it or add a condition to it.
adj. inharmonious; in disagreement
Variation blossomed when the three dancers came together, casually strutting on releve while singing assorted tones: not quite dissonant, not quite harmonious, definitely beautiful.
The composition is dissonant and eerie, invoking fear in the listener, perhaps like the fear felt by people crossing the border.
If things don't go together well, you can call them dissonant. Dissonant voices are saying different things. Dissonant clothing choices clash. Dissonant chords lack harmony.
n. corruption by sensuality; intemperance; wild living
adj. unpredictable or wandering
The erratic weather pattern has put many skiers and snowboarders into panic mode, but there should be worthwhile options throughout the holidays.
Newton is the crazy, erratic and spoiled one who will never live up to his potential.
He was relatively new to the building; he had developed a reputation for erratic behavior in the hallways and was sometimes incoherent, two residents said.
The adjective erratic describes things that are unpredictable, unusual, and that deviate from the norm
adj. extra; unnecessary
adj. serving no useful purpose; having no excuse for being
Each decision must be reviewed by a second tribunal, a step reformers say is superfluous and should be eliminated.
"Which of these rights, I ask, would we wish to discard? Are any of them trivial, superfluous, unnecessary? Are any them un-British?"
Effective writing minimizes emotions, omits superfluous words, and is succinct.
When something is so unnecessary that it could easily be done away with, like a fifth wheel on a car or a fifth person on a double date, call it superfluous.
adj. frivolously shallow and disrespectful
It's easy to flippant about rights for others when you can take your own for granted.
The e-mails depict him both as terse chief executive and a sometimes flippant writer who sprinkled his messages with "awesome," "my bad" and "chill out."

When a parent scolds a teenager for missing a curfew or blowing off a test and the teen snaps back, "Whatever," you could say the teen is being flippant. His reply was casual to the point of sarcasm and disrespect.
adj. without preparation; on the spur of the moment
adv. without advance preparation
In Zimbabwe, satirical writers such as Silvanos Mudzvova stage impromptu street theater performance as a way of evading censors and the police.
The adjective impromptu describes things done or said without previous thought or preparation.
v. choosing or draw the best from many sources
The 18-song long album is an eclectic mix of everything from pop to rock, all with a vintage 60's vibe.
Don't be afraid to step out of your comfort zone and break the matching habit to create an appealing, eclectic look in your apartment

The word can refer to any assemblage of varied parts. You can have an eclectic group of friends, eclectic taste in furniture, or enjoy eclectic cuisine (fusion cooking that uses ingredients from different national cuisines)
v. cause to become widely known
Disseminate means to spread information, knowledge, opinions widely. Semin- derives from the Latin word for seed; the idea with disseminate is that information travels like seeds sown by a farmer.
n. a person from whom you are descended
v. to refrain from, to abstain
"I know not why it is, but my heart is so full for you all that I cannot forbear from writing to tell you.
He had his gun in his hand, but forbore to fire, lest he should alarm any Esquimaux who might possibly be in the neighborhood.
The grandson bears a physical resemblance to his forbear that has often been invoked to help solidify the public's embrace.
A forbear is an ancestor or any person you are descended from, like your grandfather or your great, great, great, great grandfather.
adj. original, unspoiled, pure
Inside, the walls and floors are pristine white, and the clear cases full of colorful candies pop out at you.
This collective approach to home decor has the effect of making everything appear pristine and cared for.
If something is pristine it's immaculately clean or has never been used. So please check your shoes before walking on a pristine white carpet.
v. making peace; attempting to resolve a dispute through goodwill
v. intended to placate
It was an important and almost conciliatory message, but one that was overshadowed - or undershadowed? - by the leader's shrunken eyebrows
Many viewed the cartoon image as a conciliatory message from the new editors of Charlie Hebdo after the carnage of the Paris attack.
Mr Zhao, who had a more liberal attitude than other leaders, favored a conciliatory approach towards the protesters

If you're in a fight with a friend and you want to end it, you should make a conciliatory gesture, such as inviting her to a party you're having. Conciliatory describe things that make other people less angry.
adj. mutual; shared; interchangeable
adj. concerning each of two or more persons or things; especially given or done in return
To witness such reciprocal pride between a father and son - particularly between a father and son as tough as these two - is sweet.
An air service agreement would also encompass things like airport fees and other reciprocal arrangements between airlines and airports.
What do these principles mean for Cuba? Reciprocal respect for each country's political and economic systems, avoiding any form of interference.

Reciprocal describes something that's the same on both sides. If you and your sister are in a big fight on a long car trip, you might resolve it through a reciprocal agreement that you'll stop poking her and she'll stop reading road signs out loud
adj. foul and run-down and repulsive; morally degraded
Conditions in the house were squalid, and the people were stripped of clothes and shoes to hinder their escape.
Those on board complained of squalid conditions, including overflowing toilets and food shortages.
a word that describes something distasteful, dirty, unattractive, and squalid behavior is dirty, too, like cheating on a test and lying about it.
adj. existing as an essential constituent or characteristic
adj. in the nature of something though not readily apparent
It's a common mistake to attribute other people's behavior to their inherent characteristics in this way.
Comedians have an inherent ability to observe human nature, Sundance Film Festival director John Cooper said.
"People have a right to know that's intrinsic or inherent," Caplan said.

We use the adjective inherent to describe attributes that are part of the essential nature of something. It's different from you being tall, rather than being a description, it has to be a quality and this quality is unchangeable.
adj. doubtful; bogus; false
adj. intended to deceive
These records can help to protect the public in cases of officer misconduct. It also protects officers from spurious complaints.
He said they were "clearly spurious medications," and expressed frustration that scrutiny had fallen immediately on him.
The hospital said some families were giving spurious reasons for not taking their loved ones back.
Something false or inauthentic is spurious. Don't trust spurious ideas and stories. Spurious statements often are lies, just as a spurious coin is a counterfeit coin - a fake.
adj. required by rule
n. the recipient of a mandate
It should be mandatory reading for all those interested in the work of think tanks, which means everyone interested in public policy.
Anyone without proof of vaccination who came in contact with the five at the clinic was put under a mandatory quarantine for 21 days.
In the US, attending school through the twelfth grade, driving on the right side of the road, and obtaining a social security number are all mandatory.
adj. not allowing anything to pass through; impenetrable
or years researchers have been warning about the growing threat of "antibiotic resistance," when bacteria changes into so-called "super-bugs" that are impervious to existing antibiotics.
This does not mean that most children of immigrant origin are impervious to France's republican values and the Enlightenment ideas that underpin them.
An impervious surface is one that can't be penetrated. The word is often followed by "to," as in "His steely personality made him impervious to jokes about his awful haircut."
n. something that is said or written that refers to or mentions another person or subject in an indirect way
n. passing reference or indirect mention
More common is, when the allusion is missed, the story loses its brilliance, its frission, sometimes it totally fails as a story.
Mr. Recchia called Mr. Grimm "a minority of one," an allusion to Republican leaders' efforts to distance themselves from his legal troubles.
Ewald gives us access to Hamlet's thought process, clarifying allusions and refreshing metaphors you may have never really heard or understood.
The main thing to remember is that an allusion is a brief hint or a quick mention. It's meant to bring to mind a particular subject, but it always avoids getting into it in great depth
n. official permission or approval
n. a mechanism of social control for enforcing a society's standards
t would be like the state saying to all medical doctors: 100 percent of patients will get well, or we'll punish and sanction you.
Our president doesn't want Congress to further sanction Iran because they might get mad and walk away from the Nuclear "negotiations. "
Sanction has two nearly opposite meanings: to sanction can be to approve of something, but it can also mean to punish, or speak harshly to. Likewise, a sanction can be a punishment or approval
adj. self-restraining; not indulging an appetite especially for food or drink
n. a person who refrains from drinking intoxicating beverages
And, indeed, one year later, 44% were abstinent from alcohol and other drugs, an excellent success rate for such a difficult population.
Someone who's abstinent is moderate and restrained, especially when it comes to consuming food and drink. A person who quits drinking alcohol completely is abstinent
n. a person who believes that people only do things to help themselves, rather than for good or sincere reasons
n. a person who does not believe that sth good will happen or that sth is important
A cynic might say that the Swiss have been busy only because they accepted so much dirty money in the first place
"Let's prove the cynics wrong, and show that politicians can indeed work together and do what's best for people they serve," he said.
Oscar Wilde defined the cynic as the one who knows the price of everything and the value of nothing.

A cynic is someone who believes that humans are selfish and that they only do something if it will benefit themselves. Cynics criticize acts of kindness and will probably tease you if you help an old lady cross the street.
adj. gloomy or dismal
He could be gregarious and filled with charm one minute, and then withdrawn and almost sullen the next.
Eliza Bent is Karla Angelica, the sullen, silent one, who lurks on the sidelines with a gaze of both judgment and longing.
If someone is dark, dour, glum, moody, morose, or sour, they're also sullen. Teenagers are often described as sullen, especially when they're being grumpy and silent
n. an expert able to appreciate a field
A connoisseur's group, not a populist one, the Hagen has made a number of gripping recordings and toured Europe extensively.
I fancy myself to be a chocolate chip cookie connoisseur but it's not really a skill that I can promote on a resume.
A connoisseur is a person who, through study and interest, has a fine appreciation for something
n. a collection of things (goods or works of art etc.) for public display
n. a systematic interpretation or explanation (usually written) of a specific topic
n. (music) the section of a movement (especially in sonata form) where the major musical themes first occur
How do you write something that could be called a time travel story without getting stuck in exposition or explanation of how it works?
Saffire Events, the company that will do the work, provides the service for many fairs and expositions, she said.
Rauner's team also hosted an exposition at a downtown convention center to showcase Illinois businesses, tourist attractions and universities.

An exposition takes place when you want to show something - like at a fair or convention for showing off goods, art, or similar wares. An exposition can also be the section of a story that explains the basics of the tale.
adj. not staying for a long time; temporary
adj. following what is done or ordinary, and perhaps not interesting
adj. following what is traditional or the way sth has been done for a long time
adj. (esp. of weapon) not nuclear
She love a conventional church wedding with the bride in traditional white.
Bitcoin is a digital currency that, unlike conventional money, is bought and sold on a peer-to-peer network independent of central control.
This word describes what is typical, normal and ordinary and that which follows accepted standards of behavior or taste
n. the science of diseases; any deviation from a healthy, normal condition
But this would be an incredible coincidence, or more likely, evidence of some terrible, criminal pathology among young black men.
In reality, it can take weeks or months from the first time a pathology is noted to when a patient receives an actual diagnosis.

Pathology is the medical term for the way a disease works. We also use pathology to describe abnormal conditions that aren't really diseases, like the pathology of Hollywood stars who live their lives in public and become obsessed with fitness.
n. an opinion that all the members of a group agree with
There is a general consensus among teachers about the need for greater security in schools.
Dr. King once said, "A genuine leader is not a searcher for consensus but a molder of consensus."
They must not shirk that responsibility by simply saying experts disagree when "someone in the world" disagrees with the consensus among experts.
When there's a consensus, everyone agrees on something. If you're going to a movie with friends, you need to reach a consensus about which movie everyone wants to see.
n. boldness; reckless daring; impertinence
n. fearless daring
"She had the audacity to keep going, even when she was mocked for being a woman and mocked for being old."
It also requires audacity, self-confidence and the courage to put one's career on the line for a project about which you are passionate.
If you have audacity then you're one daring - and perhaps reckless - character. So someone who shows audacity makes bold moves - and isn't afraid of the consequences.
adj. brief and to the point; effectively cut short
He and Grant made an interesting duo: Sherman garrulous, Grant laconic and determined.
Her laconic father was more talkative, though, in his native tongue.

Laconic is an adjective that describes a style of speaking or writing that uses only a few words, often to express complex thoughts and ideas. A more laconic way to write that last sentence might be this: laconic means brief.
adj. incompetent and ineffectual;
adj. lack of perceptiveness or judgment or finesse
A clumsy, incompetent person - or an ineffective action - is inept. When you're inept, you don't know what you're doing or just can't get it done.
v. to take a claim of disagreement to court
"North Carolina did not litigate its cases. They should have as much right to petition the Supreme Court for review as Virginia has."
They decide whether to litigate in court if they want to stop the transaction.
To litigate is to engage in some sort of legal proceedings. If you're litigating, you'd better have a lawyer: you're involved in some sort of legal situation.
adj. charming in a rustic way, naturally peaceful
adj. excellent and delightful in all respects
Remodelista rounds up 11 of Italy's most idyllic farmhouses to rent for a relaxing retreat.
The Harry Potter author's novel is set in the idyllic fictional village of Pagford but reveals a town at war.
A week at the beach that goes perfectly is an idyllic vacation. Idyllic means so wonderful it seems almost magical.
v. to feel or express great sadness or disappointment about sth/sb
n. a song, poem or other expression of great sadness for sb who has died or sth that has ended
She laments that too many young women these days are trying to emulate the Kardashians instead of channeling their inner Mary Ann.
Participants are asked to distill their "experiences, questions, hopes, dreams, laments, or observations about race and identity" into a six word sentence.
Mourning will not accomplish anything; in fact it will probably empower terrorists knowing that their targets will not retaliate but just congregate together and lament.
If you are really upset or sorry about something, you might lament it. A lament is full of regret and grief
v. to carry out
v. to confirm, to back up with evidence
He also acknowledged that some officers in the department might feel pressure to lie in order to corroborate a partner's story.
He added that investigators were interviewing others to corroborate the man's story, as well as examining evidence from the scene.
If you swear to your teacher that you didn't throw the spitball, and your friends corroborate your story by confirming that you were concentrate to your homework, she might actually believe you.
v. to do clever tricks such as make sth appear or disappear as if by magic
v. to make sth appear as a picture in your mind
v. to make sb/sth appear by using special magic words
Ebola, however much some of its symptoms conjure up a horror film, is usually shockingly simple to treat.
One innovation firm is trying to make the magic a little easier to conjure.
To conjure Beetlejuice one would have to say his name three times and he would be summoned from his grave.
If your mom can magically conjure up the most delicious meals from the most random ingredients in the kitchen, she might just be the best cook in the neighborhood
n. a dreamer; someone with impractical goals or ideas about the future
adj. not practical or realizable; speculative
"Apple has been very visionary in creating and expanding significant new consumer electronics categories," Mr. Sacconaghi said.
A Fortune magazine investigation showed Musk not merely as a visionary but also a master manipulator with a shaky deal.
You've got big ideas. Crazy ideas. But forward thinking ideas - ideas that just might change the way the world works. You're considered a visionary.
n. a comparison made between two things
adj. implied; not spoken
Some might view Obama's recent actions as a strategic correction-as a tacit acknowledgment that his earlier approach to foreign policy failed.
It's a tacit acknowledgment that his inability to connect with everyday Americans hurt him, as he repeatedly made costly remarks about money and class.
Something tacit is implied or understood without question. Holding hands might be a tacit acknowledgment that a boy and girl are dating.
adj. angered at something unjust or wrong
"I want to serve,'' I told him, trying to sound self-righteous, not indignant. "It would be my civic honor.''
Revolutionaries get indignant about police abuse or ruthless capitalism, and then forgive, in the name of the revolution, every injustice they had otherwise denounced.
When you're indignant, you're angry about an unfair situation. If you discovered that a teacher gave ten extra points on a test to all students who sat in the front row, you'd be indignant.
v. bring about abruptly
n. fall from clouds
adj. happening very quickly or suddenly and usually without enough care and thought
Prematurely raising interest rates could precipitate the very crash that the Bank of England has spent six years trying to prevent.
Such a scenario would precipitate a dramatic weakening of the ruble, forcing the central bank into action.
Several weeks later, I warned that the energy sector could help precipitate a correction in the stock market.
Precipitate usually means "bringing something on" or "making it happen" - and not always in a good way
n. an extremely talented child; an extraordinary accomplishment or occurrence.
Joey Alexander, an 11-year-old piano prodigy from Indonesia, played his arrangement of Thelonious Monk's " 'Round Midnight," technically fluent and harmonically astute.
"I think that people think if you grow up as a child prodigy then life is really easy for you," Eugenie says.

A prodigy is someone who is so naturally talented at something that they become a master of that particular skill as a child. Mozart was one, writing symphonies and playing for kings when he was only five years old.
adj. impervious to external influence; airtight
adj. cheerful and pleasant; friendly; helpful
adj. agreeable, conducive to comfort
He was, true to everything I had read and heard about him, genial and charming.
He is a genial character, well known and well liked.
A shrewd and genial host, he serves perfect frozen margaritas and supports local school sports
If you're friendly and outgoing, you're genial. You can be a genial host or a genial guest.
adj. having a firm basis in reality and being therefore important, meaningful, or considerable
Both men said Obama's visit to India has been more than symbolic and yielded substantive progress on trade, defense and climate issues.
"More importantly, I think it's fair to say most controversies described using '-gate' fall well short of the substantive importance or evidentiary basis of Watergate."
When you talk about substantive change, you mean change that really makes a difference. After a substantive discussion, you will have an in depth understanding of what you are talking about.
